But on ceasing to be infans the pupil was held to acquire a power of volition‚ and thereby capacity of disposition, yet bis laclr of intellectual powers was thought likely to betray him into transactions by which be might be injured, and thus the rule was established, that for all acts by which the pupil could possibly injure his proprietary interests the guardian’s auctoritas was necessary, though the former was regarded as himself the acting party, especially in dispositions which were iuris civilis, and therefore ‘procura- torem non recipiebant ς’ see Tit. 21. pr. inf, and cf. tbe note on Bk iii. rp ro referred to. § 3. The right of the paterfamilias to appoint by his will tutors to such females in bis power as would become sui iuris on his decease, and to such males in the same position as were impuberes, was established, if not for the first time conferred, by the Xll Tables: ‘testamento quoque nominatim tutores dati confirmantur eadem lege duodecim tabularum, his verbis: uti legassit super pecunia tutelave suae rei, ita ius esto: qui tutores dativi appellantur’ Ulpiau, reg. 11. 14. The intended tutor must have testamentifactio witb the testator, and Latini Iuniani could not be thus appointed, Gaius i. 24 lt would seem that a testamentary guardian could at one time decline the office, or even lay it down after acceptance, Ulpian, reg. 11. 17 : thia right is not mentioned in Justinian, which marks the transition from tbe conception of tutela as a right to that of a munus publicum.
